sen.j: 名草 戸畔（なぐさ とべ、? - 伝 紀元前663年旧暦6月）は、日本書紀や和歌山市の伝承に登場する、神武東征と戦った人物である。
sen.e: Nagusatobe (year of birth unknown - the month attributed to June in old lunar calendar in 663 B.C.) was a person having fought against the Jinmu tosei (story in Japanese myth about the first generation of the Imperial family) who have appeared in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) and legends in Wakayama City.

Nagusatobe (year of birth unknown - the month attributed to June in old lunar calendar in 663 B.C.) was a person having fought against the Jinmu tosei (story in Japanese myth about the first generation of the Imperial family) who have appeared in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) and legends in Wakayama City.

Nagusatobe (year of birth unknown - the month attributed to June in old lunar calendar in 663 B.C.) was a person having fought against the Jinmu tosei (story in Japanese myth about the first generation of the Imperial family) who have appeared in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) and legends in Wakayama City.
Nagusatobe was a woman according to legend.
Nagusatobe was a woman according to legend.
Nagusatobe was a woman according to legend.

sen.j: 名草戸畔は日本書紀での名で、地元では名草姫（なぐさひめ）とも。
sen.e: While Nagusatobe was the name in Nihonshoki, she was also called Nagusahime locally.
While Nagusatobe was the name in Nihonshoki, she was also called Nagusahime locally.
While Nagusatobe was the name in Nihonshoki, she was also called Nagusahime locally.

sen.j: 一説に、名草戸畔とは特定の人名ではなく、「名草の長」という地位を表す言葉であるという。
sen.e: According to one view, Nagusatobe is said not to have been the name of a specific person but the expression indicating a status of 'chief of Nagusa region.'
According to one view, Nagusatobe is said not to have been the name of a specific person but the expression indicating a status of 'chief of Nagusa region.'
According to one view, Nagusatobe is said not to have been the name of a specific person but the expression indicating a status of 'chief of Nagusa region.'

sen.j: 名草邑（のちの名草郡あたり、現在の和歌山市名草山周辺）の統治者だった。
sen.e: She was the ruler of Nagusa village (Later Nagusa County and the area around the present Mt. Nagusa in Wakayama City.
She was the ruler of Nagusa village (Later Nagusa County and the area around the present Mt. Nagusa in Wakayama City.
She was the ruler of Nagusa village (Later Nagusa County and the area around the present Mt. Nagusa in Wakayama City.

sen.j: しかし、神武東征で進軍中だったイワレヒコ（のちの神武天皇）との戦いで戦死した。
sen.e: She was, however, killed in battle against Kamuyamatoiwarebiko (Later Emperor Jimmu) who had been on the march in the Jinmu tosei.
She was, however, killed in battle against Kamuyamatoiwarebiko (Later Emperor Jimmu) who had been on the march in the Jinmu tosei.
She was, however, killed in battle against Kamuyamatoiwarebiko (Later Emperor Jimmu) who had been on the march in the Jinmu tosei.

sen.j: 名草戸畔の死後は、代わって紀氏が紀伊国を治めた。
sen.e: After the death of Nagusatobe, the Ki clan instead ruled Ki Province.
After the death of Nagusatobe, the Ki clan instead ruled Ki Province.
After the death of Nagusatobe, the Ki clan instead ruled Ki Province.

sen.j: 紀氏は、自らの系図で名草戸畔を遠縁に位置づけることで、正当性を主張した。
sen.e: Ki clan insisted on their legitimacy by listing Nagusatobe as distantly-related in their own family tree.
Ki clan insisted on their legitimacy by listing Nagusatobe as distantly-related in their own family tree.
Ki clan insisted on their legitimacy by listing Nagusatobe as distantly-related in their own family tree.
Nihonshoki
Nihonshoki
Nihonshoki

sen.j: 日本書紀では、「巻第三 神武天皇即位前紀 戊午年旧暦6月」冒頭が、名草戸畔や名草邑に関する唯一の記述である。
sen.e: In Nihonshoki, the beginning of 'The third volume, July in the Tsuchinoe Uma year before the accession of Emperor Jinmu to the throne according to the lunar calendar' was
sen.cmt: 年号はサイトや辞書でも掲載がなく、やむを得ず左の訳としました。
sen.e: In Nihonshoki, the beginning of 'The third volume, July in the Tsuchinoe Uma year before the accession of Emperor Jinmu to the throne according to the lunar calendar' was

In Nihonshoki, the beginning of 'The third volume, July in the Tsuchinoe Uma year before the accession of Emperor Jinmu to the throne according to the lunar calendar' was the only reference to Nagusatobe and Nagusa village.
sen.cmt: 原文・訳文を一文にする

sen.j: 紀元前660年とされる神武天皇即位の3年前のことである。
sen.e: The above had happened three years before the accession of Emperor Jinmu to the throne which is considered to have been in 660 B.C.
The above had happened three years before the accession of Emperor Jinmu to the throne which is considered to have been in 660 B.C.
The above had happened three years before the accession of Emperor Jinmu to the throne which is considered to have been in 660 B.C.

sen.j: 神武の兄五瀬命の死の後、狭野を越え熊野神邑から再度海路を征く前の話である。
sen.e: It was a story about the expedition Emperor Jinmu again went on by sea from Kumano-shin village after crossing through Sano, following the death of Itsuse no mikoto, an elder brother of Emperor Jinmu.

It was a story about the expedition Emperor Jinmu again went on by sea from Kumano-shin village after crossing through Sano, following the death of Itsuse no mikoto, an elder brother of Emperor Jinmu.

It was a story about the expedition Emperor Jinmu again went on by sea from Kumano-shin village after crossing through Sano, following the death of Itsuse no mikoto, an elder brother of Emperor Jinmu.
Legend
Legend
Legend

sen.j: 地元の伝承は次のように伝える。
sen.e: The local legend describes the following story.
The local legend describes the following story.
The local legend describes the following story.

sen.j: 熊野古道を現海南市に少し入ったそばのクモ池周辺が戦場になった。
sen.e: The area around Kumo-ike Pond off Kumanokodo Road a little into the present Kainan City turned into a battlefield.
The area around Kumo-ike Pond off Kumanokodo Road a little into the present Kainan City turned into a battlefield.
The area around Kumo-ike Pond off Kumanokodo Road a little into the present Kainan City turned into a battlefield.

sen.j: 名草戸畔はここで殺され、頭、胴、足（脚の意か）が切り離された。
sen.e: Nagusatobe was killed here and the body was cut off into head, torso and foot (means legs ?).
Nagusatobe was killed here and the body was cut off into head, torso and foot (or legs).
Nagusatobe was killed here and the body was cut off into head, torso and foot (or legs).

sen.j: 名草の住民により、頭は宇賀部神社（別名おこべさん）、胴は杉尾神社（別名おはらさん）、足は千種神社（別名あしがみさん）に埋葬された。
sen.e: Nagusa villagers buried the head in Ukabe-jinja Shrine (another name, Okobesan), the torse in Sugio-jinja Shrine (another name, Oharasan) and the legs in Chigusa-jinja Shrine (Ashigamisan).
Nagusa villagers buried the head in Ukabe-jinja Shrine (another name, Okobesan), the torse in Sugio-jinja Shrine (another name, Oharasan) and the legs in Chigusa-jinja Shrine (Ashigamisan).
Nagusa villagers buried the head in Ukabe-jinja Shrine (another name, Okobesan), the torse in Sugio-jinja Shrine (another name, Oharasan) and the legs in Chigusa-jinja Shrine (Ashigamisan).

sen.j: 和歌山市のいくつかの神社は名草姫命（名草戸畔）と名草彦命を祀っており、その本社は吉原の中言神社である。
sen.e: Some of the shrines in Wakayama City are dedicated to Nagusahime no mikoto (Nagusatobe) or Nagusahiko no mikoto and their main shrine is Nakagoto-jinja Shrine.
Some of the shrines in Wakayama City are dedicated to Nagusahime no mikoto (Nagusatobe) or Nagusahiko no mikoto and their main shrine is Nakagoto-jinja Shrine.
Some of the shrines in Wakayama City are dedicated to Nagusahime no mikoto (Nagusatobe) or Nagusahiko no mikoto and their main shrine is Nakagoto-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 名草姫命と名草彦命の関係ははっきりしない。
sen.e: The relationship between Nagusahime no mikoto and Nagusahiko no mikoto is not clear.
The relationship between Nagusahime no mikoto and Nagusahiko no mikoto is not clear.
The relationship between Nagusahime no mikoto and Nagusahiko no mikoto is not clear.
